data.content: Both have this mysterious aura where it makes you think for yourself instead of spelling it out for you. And both are messed up in their own ways
both the heroines are from elf race. both protag did it with a family of elf.

data.content: both the heroines are from elf race. both the main elf looks like forest elf (blonde, green clothing, lives in the woods). both are somewhat comedic.

• Both are coming of age story which centre around a low esteem female lead. Both the story focuses on MC's growth and there is lots of emotional and heartwarming event throughout the series. • Both have beautiful art and animation. Kinda give similar vibes. • My happy marriage is more romance oriented where else Violet Evergarden is episodic and doesn't focuses much on romance until the very end of the series (movie).
A forced marriage in a non modern setting. Yhey are just alike

The characters in Bungou Stray Dogs are anime characters inspired by classic literature authors. In Undead Murder Farce, literary characters are referenced as being in the world like Frankenstein, Sherlock Holmes and Count Dracula. They both live in supernatural worlds with a Victorian-inspired aesthetic. Both shows have a detective elements and are action-packed with mature storytelling about adults. Both shows are very character-driven. The characters are well-written and deep and the heart of the shows.There’s mastermind characters in both.
They are both sports anime where the characters drive the plot. The majority of the characters are fun and enjoyable when they are on screen and the relationships are great!

The character interactions and relationships are similar. The vibe of the school environment is the same: relaxed, present without taking over the plot, and suits the characters. Both plots are wrapped up from beginning to end, contained within one season.

If you liked Akame ga kill I think you would most definitely like Guilty Crown. They are both about assassins/terrorist groups trying to stop a corrupt government system. Both shows have great Main Characters and a good female cast. Both shows are complete and you can finish both of these in a day.

-Both long battle shonen series with similar power systems with numerous attributes -Big use of illusions during both series -Similar aspect of leadership and the main characters trying to become boss of the vongola/hokage, though tsuna is very reluctant to become boss while Naruto it is his main goal.
Experimental shorts on showing fluid animation on a white background. Wonder tries to be more meaningful, while Superfluid goes the abstract way. Both are really colorful tho.
Two shorts that use memes from the era, Nagisa no Brazilian aged particularly terribly in that aspect and possibly Show in Backrooms will age pretty bad as well.

entry.title: Haikara-san ga Tooru Movie 1: Benio, Hana no 17-sai

data.content: Both feature strong female leads , determined women who are not afraid to stand up for what they believe in. Both anime explores themes of love, loss, and hope. I also love Haikara-san and was recommended My happy marriage because a friend said they were similar

Definitely a different direction from Stand Alone Complex, still it retains human dilemma of coping with the loss of oneself on the surface level this seems the ol "ship of theseus" paradox visualized into 1 and a half hour feature film

Each anime is a romantic comedy dealing with a more committed relationship between adults. They've got a bit of supernatural spice, but the majority of the setting is realistic. If you love romance focused on the relationship itself instead of on the will they/won't they part of romance, these are for you! Be aware that Tonikaku is much more comedic, while Otonari focuses more on the romance.

- Time jumping is a big element - Thriller and mystery - Both have pretty great animation - Vivy is more scifi based whereas SR is more supernatural - Main protag is tasked with changing outcome of events
Cat and mouse detective game, twists your perception of good and evil and the embodiment of them.

Both are about orphaned girls working since a young age as assassins working under a secret organization that fights against terrorism. While Gunslinger Girl is a very serious and gritty drama, Lycoris Recoil is a lot more moe and light hearted.

Artificial intelligence in science fiction media has become an increasingly relevant theme as AI technologies continue to improve. Summer Wars and Vivy are very different from each other, but showcase the dangers of AI. In Vivy, you have a more nuanced interpretation of a Skynet AI. In Summer Wars, you have a self-aware, hacking AI that is causing havoc on digital infrastructure. If you're interested in AI takeover in science fiction then you should consider this recommendation.

Both feature a fun, over-powered protagonist and insane, over-the-top action. Both worlds feel alive with the amount of cool characters and crazy moments within both shows. Also, both manga were created by ONE (go figure).

Both of these shows are similar and akin to Romaniticed Asian period pieces that really reflect on the sensibilities of Eastern Asian History & Culture. I say that reservably; as Saiunkoku Monogatari can be interpreted and seen in a lens of a Chinese Imperial Era literature or even akin to Korean Joseon Period era literature. In this case, My Happy Marriage is set in a period akin to the Meiji Era. All play into the following important factors: They revolve around marriage arrangements that's serve as a means to deal with political and family-clan issues. Characters from both shows learn to deal with the tribulations of the broader picture and eventually grow fonder with one another. Romance can develop but is usually overshadowed by socio-political and external factors. Saiunkoku Monogatari is more lighthearted and more Shoujo (but doesn't shy away from serious dramatic storylines & political topics) whereas My Happy Marriage has more Josei undertones with a more serious and dramatic direction. If you like a romanticised Asian period type stories that doesn't feel like your typical anime; then these shows are perfect for you.

Like in Tokyo Ghoul, there are 3 sides in Bleach: The Soul Reapers are like the CCG, the Hollows are like the evil ghouls, and Ishigo and his squad is like Kanagi's. Kanagi is half human half ghoul, and Ishigo is part human, part soul reaper, but also part hollow

Anime that might be classified hentai. but they have an actual storyline, not just one to serve as an excuse for the plot. And considering both have assasing protagonists, there is also a focus on action scenes.

Animes are good for when you are very still, tired of the usual shonen and want to watch something different.... That's it... Different!!!! Animes like this are for the real roots Otakus who don't bother with the less hyped and give a chance to just enjoy the story... I recommend it, not for total similarity, but for that pinch of innocent comedy with a little family value and a dose of cuteness!!! <portuguese>Os animes são bem para quando você está muito paradão, cansado do shonen costumeiro e quer assistir algo diferente.... É isso... Diferente!!!! Animes assim são para os verdadeiros Otakus raízes que não se frescuram com os menos hypados e dá uma chance de, apenas, curtir a história... Recomendo, não por semelhança total, mas por aquela pitada de comédia inocente com um pouco de valor familiar e uma dose de fofura!!! </portuguese>

They both play with the idea of a group of characters who put on a different personality for their guests' entertainment at their job/club. Ouran goes a little deeper with it, while Blend S chooses to focus on a romance as the series progresses, but both shows are at their best when they're exploring who these characters really are in contrast to the roles they play.
Good Dark Animes
Very Good Dark Animes
Both are very good some of the best Psychological Anime ever created

If you've seen Oshi no Ko, you should definitely watch Bakuman. Bakuman follows the behind-the-scenes of the manga industry in the same way Oshi no Ko follows the idol industry. Bakuman is about two boys who are determined to make a successful manga. The series details the struggles, successes, failures, and personal lives of the two main characters. Though Bakuman follows the ins and outs of the manga industry, it is ultimately more lighthearted than Oshi no Ko but is still a very good watch and is a very inspiring series.

An important aspect of these series is the relationship between a mentor and student. Kai (Piano no Mori) was satisfied with playing piano for himself until his mentor shows him that there is so much more to learn from the piano. Minato (Tsurune) had resigned himself from never practicing archery again after losing his self-confidence. A chance encounter with his mentor inspires him to pick up archery again and begin recovering his confidence. These mentors do not simply teach, but challenge their students to find their own answers and discover new depth for their passions. As you can guess, both series focuses on character growth.
These works explore AI that have gained humanlike consciousness and the ramifications of such. The subject has a portrayal that skews positive in regards to both tone and narrative.
a ordinary school boy that needed to protect by a girl, they have a satisfyin romance and action; plus it has more depth.
It has shinobis, action and a lot of similar things to naruto, i highly reccomend it

I’m not the first person to point out the distinct similarity between the vibe of these anime, but it’s worth noting. The ways in which the characters interact is nearly identical, as well as the style of humour.
Both are about noisy animation that sychronize with the music. Incredibly short and creative.
Both of the Series start off with a lot of ecchi moments and weird concepts but then they have sudden plot twists which change your view of the show.
Similar story with the mc killing bad guys and threats but in an Isekai setting with great world-building. The cast has similar chemistry. It has some really dark themes like this.
Both anime are about an eccentric group of people using supernatural powers to fight against strange crimes in their cities. They appeal to a similar sense of humor while also having dark undertones.

They are both vampire based, have intimacy in it and etc. I'll just say that vanitas no karte has a much better storyline and indulges the viewers better than diabolik lovers. Although, vanitas no karte focuses more on the story line so it does have as many 'bite' scenes in it but the ones that are, are very romantic and sexy~ One more thing, it is not a harem or reverse harem like diabolik lovers but you'll definitely still like it~

These both anime are quite literally similar in their own way. So, in bsd every ability holder has a unique ability they are born with, while in high card (I'm calling it HC) there are 52 cards that have chosen their own owners. In HC there is a type of 'agency' just like the ADA. There are many more similarities and both have amazing Art styles!

Both anime takes place in a world where humanity is about to go extinct. The protagonists are young in both the anime and I find the themes of love, friendship, loyalty etc. very similar. Both series involve secretive organizations and governments that keep hidden truths from the general population.

Well, first of, they are literally both from the same Writer and illustrator (Jun Mochizuki). They dont have similar characters but the similarity is that, just like vanitas no Karte has a unique world of vampires to itself, in pandora hearts there is a unique world of 'Chains'. Both have an immense amount of Angst and both are supernatural. A difference is Pandora hearts doesnt have a main love interest since the MC is only 15 (he does have a crush tho) and I suggest reading the manga after u finish the anime because it shows only the introduction to the whole thing
They are both wholesome, both have a kid in it, both are spy based, both contain comedy, both have a bit, like the amount of a grain of salt, angst. One can't cook while the other is exceptional!

First of, both are based on music, both have a MC that is struggling, there setting is quite the same, both MC's are child competition winners ( you can say they are child prodigies but I believe they worked hard so...) . Although, its just different instruments and Ao no Orchestra has a much more refreshing ending to it (I believe, I'm not sure because it hasn't ended yet)

Both MC are orphaned highschool girls including elements of fantasy/shoujo. Kamisama Kiss begins very similar to Fruits Basket as Nanami is kicked out of her apartment & meets Tomoe where she is invited to live at their shrine. Kamisama Kiss & Fruits Basket have the same director. Although, Kamisama Kiss is a bit shorter than Fruits Basket.

Some of the flashback scenes in Only Yesterday happen almost exactly like scenes in Naisho no Tsubomi. Both involve young girls learning more about crushes, relationships and even their own bodies and of course endless teasing from their male classmates about these issues.

Death Note & Monster both share themes of Justice. Death Note is a supernatural thriller focused on psychological warfare while Monster is a grounded suspense/mystery series. There are some noted parallel scenes.
Characters masquerading as someone they are not but eventually turning lies into truths.

gritty urban sci-fi settings, ensemble casts with checkered histories, complex heists/fetch quests, dystopic lore implications, hacker characters, jaw-dropping action scenes that usually result in a large structure exploding into rubble, unhinged ladies, child endangerment- what more could you ask for? cd projekt red devs will cry, throw up and quake in their boots just thinking about how flawlessly these two shows exemplify the cyberpunk aesthetic and it's core themes.

sol comedy in which a goofy strawberry blonde girl pesters a grumpy black-haired boy. aho girl's jokes are dirtier and less referential, but it's structurally similar and tonally identical to umaru overall. each have side characters that fit into the obsessive stalker/yandere archetype (fuuki and kirie) and mild mannered best friend archetype (sayaka and ebina). aho-girl lacks the variation in conflict that umaru's dual persona provides, but if you like this particular style of overexaggerated humor, both will scratch that itch.

similar sense of humor/general vibe, and the male protags are reminiscent of each other. both shows include absurdist subversions of japan's costumed mascot phenomenon, as well as what i'd refer to as a "hybrid" setup, where the base plot is essentially a combination of two common anime settings (school + military in fumoffu, ancient japan + sci-fi in gintama). released around the same time so they have practically the same animation style. more of a rec for fumoffu -> gintama since the latter is much longer and higher quality.

both main casts are part of a covert law enforcement organization comprised almost entirely of schoolgirls trained to neutralize domestic terror events. if i had a penny for how many times this has been an anime premise, i'd have 2 pennies, which isn't a lot but its weird that it happened twice. also has romantic tension between two of the females leads and a slow-burn mystery in common. lycoris is better imo

Hell's Paradise is one of the standout series from Spring 2023. It was especially beloved for its non-stop action and graphic violence. Like Ninja Scroll, Hell's Paradise is set in Edo-period Japan and has ninjas, swordsmen, and supernatural creatures killing each other. Their storylines simply provide a reason for characters to fight, which is what you want in these types of anime.
They both have same vibe, and the artstyle is so amazing. If you liked your name you will love this one too.
Made by the same studio as AoT and was inspired by AoT heavily

- MC is a young woman recovering from some traumatic event - MC relies on an older man to teach her certain things - Theme of learning what it means to be human (e.g., feel emotions) - Settings inspired by rural Europe Thought where Violet is trying to learn what love is, Chise is trying to teach Elias about humanity, the way they convey these things is similar.

Eve's music videos often contain many strange creatures that inherit strange abilities, holding a metaphorical purpose in order to explain psychological states of the characters that interact with them. Cencoroll almost uses this same formula, instead prioritizing the evolving narrative more heavily in comparison while using these creatures to give the characters extra emotional depth as they progress through the story. Eve's music videos would likely also take this form if they were longer and had more time for plot development.

entry.title: Youkoso Jitsuryoku Shijou Shugi no Kyoushitsu e

data.content: Both have plots that revolve around a competitive educational setting, with thematic developments hinging, at its core, between the social life and relationships between classmates. Due to this format, both hold similarly suspicious authoritarian undertones.

If you like good mystery stories that tend to lean more into a darker theme, then you'll like Undead Girl Murder Farce. Both stories actually have Sherlock Holmes and Moriarty, although in a different way, and both lean into the darker side of mystery as well as society. Also both have very interesting main characters and interesting side mysteries.
If you like trash romance drama, then White Album is the trash in the dumpster fire that was Domestic Girlfriend
It's the same show, but 18 years later, for the kids that missed it the first time round. Time is a flat circle.
Moe schoolgirls gushing over motorbikes. Pretty much an advertisment with namedropping brands and such.

Undead Girl Murder Farce and Baccano are pretty similar to each other, they both are Mystery Shows with supernatural aspects and stuff to do with Immortals. Both take place outside of Japan, both have some pretty good comedy and excellent fight scenes
Both are about the dark world behind idols, Perfect Blue explains it better in my opinion.
Both are avant garde shorts that show people dancing crazily to the music.

Kai (Piano no Mori) and Yuri (Yuri!!! on Ice) are very different characters, but are shaped by their relationships with their mentors and rivals. Although Kai is a naturally gifted and confident pianist, his mentor helps him to unlock his full potential and introduces him to piano competitions. Yuri is an aging figure skater with anxiety problems, but his new coach unlocks his artistry and confidence. They are also greatly shaped by their admiration for their rivals - Yuri Plisetsky (Yuri!!! on Ice) and Shuuhei Amamiya (Piano no Mori). If these elements are the aspects that you enjoyed then you should consider this recommendation.

In a dystopian future with the most state-of-the-art tech, one would imagine that you could be all-trusting to the all-objective, and justice seeking AI. But all that glitters isn't gold in Vivy's and Psycho-Pass: Providence. Society struggles to stay attached at the thread, and even the most perfect member's of society struggle to balance their sanity and societal expectations of them. Really recommend both as the music and voice actors are absolutely excellent. The directing at some parts were very reminiscent of each other. And overall, if you'd like to ponder what like would be like 100 years from now, or if AIs ever took over the world-- these are both amazing series that tackle a lot of nuances issues.
Both are about young boys and are comedy anime. The relationship they have with each other and their dynamic is just too good.
Both tackle emotion and android character development. Action packed and have banger ost

- Deals with time jumping with an element of photography/capturing images that is central to both stories - Suspenseful thrillers where the mystery unfolds slowly - Both have really cute ikemen as the MC - Bingeworthy and will make you tear up

data.content: These shows are both comedies featuring a washed-up middle-aged former hero reminiscing about his days of adventure and struggling with life once those adventures are over. They have some similar plot points and comedy styles. Both shows feature an impressive mix of comedic and serious tones.

War's toll on civilians.

Both shows play with the same idea, but one is harem with fanservice while the other is vanilla and more innocent. Oddly enough, in the more innocent show, the male lead is much more successful at pursuing relationship with the older girl. If you liked one, maybe you'll find something to like in the other one, though one of those shows is much better.
• Both the anime centred around time travel. • Both are psychological thriller with lots of action. • Both the anime have lots of emotional moments.

If you like Sabage-Bu, D-Frag is pretty much the go-to anime AND manga. Also features rivalry, hilarious plots, disconnected chapters driven by gag humor. The difference is D-Frag has love polygon elements (but since it's one-sided, it just becomes an additional angle for gag) and the level of satire in D-Frag is not as ruthless as Sabage-bu references and takes.

Going to an elite school separating magic/tech use by skill level turns out to not be valid, because it's the dropouts/barely passing the mark boys who accidentally are the most OP. Without trying they seem to get a harem/loyal support group of equally elite girls. Both are battle of the fittest type anime. Two series with great art styles, but toe the line of overusing certain archetypes/phrases.

data.content: Looking for a very fan-service heavy harem-y style series with pretty character designs and an OP magic user? Both have a fairly low cliffhanger plot, and similar archetypes. Easy to watch if you don't mind the tsunderes and "you'll like me because, I'm cute ehe" types

Similar setting, MCs related to the world of organized crime that have to look after a child (one because of an order and the others because of a coincidence) Also both stories mix in comedy with drama bits, while they learn how to be a family with the context they live in
Similar historical Victorian Europe setting, with vampires and other supernatural creatures, and a MC group that solves mysteries

MC joins a group of criminals that goes against the government/system to achieve something (not necessarily the same thing in both shows tho) A difference is that Akudama Drive has a more futuristic/cyberpunk setting compared to AgK's

entry.title: Kono Subarashii Sekai ni Shukufuku wo!

data.content: Isekai Quartet is an isekai with Chibi characters in which characters from other isekai join a school and among its characters there are also characters from KonoSuba.
Both are one of the most creepiest and darkest post-apocalyptic projects in anime. Both have such an intriguing plot, brutal & merciless world building and a very in-depth character development
Both start from the walls, both have a lot of suspense and interesting moments. Also, have a dozen creepy & gore moments
both take place in a magical world where the protagonist instead of magic has strength and joins a group of wizards
Both are great romance movies that are very emotional and can leave you feeling heartbroken.
Azumanga Daioh and K-on are both incredibly peaceful shows about cute girls doing cute things and simply enjoying life with mostly no worries in the world.
Monster and Death Note are both detective fiction pieces with unique and creative twists that constantly keep you at the edge of your seat.
Both shows have incredibly cute toddler-range girls who make extremely silly faces. The girls and their affinity for their parents and making them happy are super similar!

In both shows the characters are children that are trapped and left in the dark. They break rules in both shows to find out how the world really is like. The promised neverland is basically a mix of Attack on Titan and Darling in the Franxx, where they are trapped between walls and raised so that demons can eat their brains. So if you've watched any of the three shows I mentioned, I recommend any of the others.

Both are animes that trick you into thinking it's cute but in reality, it's not, if you want an anime that is darker than Madoka Magica then Magical Girl Site is the way to start. Magical Girl Site is truly terrifying and is also very emotional.

Two melancholic anime, with a mostly calm setting but with psychological/supernatural aspects, a mystery that surrounds the town the people live at, mysterious dreams, and people wishing to fly either metaphorically or literally. Both also present the topics of loss. The biggest difference is that AIR has some Harem/Romance elements and Haibane Renmei is mostly a Slice of Life.

Chihayafuru and Dance Dance Danseur are character-focused series about non-traditional competitions. Chihaya (Chihayafuru) and Junpei (Dance Dance Danseur) are underdogs who have less experience and knowledge than their peers, but are determined to become the best. They must push themselves to improve with the help of friends and rivals. Dance Dance Danseur is less known than Chihayafuru, but its audience certainly overlaps.
Girls being girls will lead to chaos! The art styles may vary between the animes but they have the same vibe and the characters are likeable too!

I feel like if you enjoyed Sasaemki Koto then you might like Nichijou, these animes are different but I feel like they have the same vibes. Both have chaotic friend groups and get themselves into situations, and the art styles are pretty similar too.

Both are masterpieces that don't shy away from darker topics and build remarkably memorable characters. While Edgerunners is far shorter, more casual and faster-paced, LoGH is a slow-burn with plenty of political intrigue, twists and heart-stopping moments. There are other reasons and general feelings behind the shows that you'd just have to watch to understand. "You can't defy your fate, after all."
